name: Average carbon footprint per salbutamol inhaler
title: Average carbon footprint per salbutamol inhaler
description: Mean average carbon impact (kg CO<sub>2</sub>e) per salbutamol inhaler prescribed
why_it_matters: committed to reducing its carbon footprint by 51% by 2025 to meet the target in the Climate Change Act, including a shift to lower carbon inhalers
now includes an indicator on mean carbon emissions per salbutamol inhaler prescribed (kg CO2e).
Whole lifecycle carbon emissions can vary substantially between different inhaler devices. Traditional metered dose inhalers (MDIs) rely on
hydrofluroalkanes (HFA) to act as a propellant to deliver doses. <a href='https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/bmjopen/9/10/e028763.full.pdf'>
HFAs are potent greenhouse gases with a potency thousands of times that of carbon dioxide. Dry powder inhalers (DPIs) do not contain HFA so they
consequently make up the lowest carbon options available for salbutamol, however DPIs may not be suitable for all patients. Even amongst MDIs there is
significant variation in CO<sub>2</sub> equivalent emissions with some having significantly lower HFA content.
